title: How to Season Roast Pork

methods.name: Pork Loin Roast with Herb Rub

steps.headline: Preheat the oven at 350 °F (177 °C) and mix your seasonings.
steps.description:
After setting the oven to preheat, place the following ingredients in a bowl and stir them together with a fork:
1.5 tsp (7.5 g) salt
1.5 tsp (7.5 g) celery salt
1 tsp (5 g) onion powder
1 tsp (5 g) garlic powder
1 tsp (5 g) paprika
1 tsp (5 g) pepper
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) dill weed
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) dried rosemary, crushed
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) rubbed sage

steps.headline: Massage the seasoning mix onto the roast.
steps.description: Sprinkle the seasoning blend onto all sides of the 4 lb (1.8 kg) pork loin so that it is evenly coated. Use your hands to gently pat and press the seasoning so that it adheres to the pork. So long as the entire pork loin is evenly coated with a nice layer of seasoning, don’t worry about any excess that falls off.

steps.headline: Place the pork loin onto a greased roasting rack in a shallow pan.
steps.description: Choose a roasting pan that’s large enough for the pork loin and has a removable roasting rack. Spray the rack liberally with cooking spray, place it into the roasting pan, then lay the pork loin on the rack. Use a shallow-sided roasting pan, if possible. This will help brown the meat on the outside.

steps.headline: Roast the pork loin for about 1.75 hours, until the internal temperature reaches 160 °F (71 °C).
steps.description: Place the pork loin in the 350 °F (177 °C) oven for 1 hour and 45 minutes. Then, check the internal temperature with a probe thermometer. If it’s under 160 °F (71 °C), return the pork loin to the oven and check it again in 5 minutes. It may take a pork loin of this size 2 hours to reach the desired internal temperature.

steps.headline: Slice and serve the roast after it rests for 10 minutes.
steps.description: After you remove the roast from the oven, cover it loosely with aluminum foil and allow it to rest. After 10 minutes, slice the pork loin as thin or thick as you like and serve it to your guests. A 4 oz (110 g) serving of this roast has under 200 calories, 7 g of fat, and 3 g of saturated fat, and just over 500 mg of sodium. Refrigerate any leftovers in an airtight container and use them within 3 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven at 375 °F (191 °C) and get a shallow roasting pan.
steps.description: While the oven heats up, place the pork loin (with the fat cap facing up) into the shallow roasting pan. A deeper roasting pan will work, but the pork won’t brown as evenly. Pork loins have a thicker layer of fat on one side known as a fat cap. The fat cap is lighter in color than the rest of the pork loin.

steps.headline: Spread the minced garlic onto the pork loin’s fat cap.
steps.description: Finely minced garlic nearly has the consistency of a chunky paste. That means you can spoon it onto the fat cap and spread it out evenly with your fingers or the back of the spoon. Use 1 tsp (5 g) of minced garlic for a 3 lb (1.4 kg) roast.

steps.headline: Mix the other seasonings and add them to the pork loin.
steps.description: Stir together 0.5 tsp (2.5 g) of kosher salt, 0.5 tsp (2.5 g) of coarse ground black pepper, and 0.25 tsp (1.25 g) of paprika in a small bowl. Use your fingers to sprinkle it onto all sides of the pork, and gently pat and press with your hands so that it adheres well. Coat the garlic on the fat cap and the other sides of the pork roast as evenly as possible. The seasoning mix will stick easily to the minced garlic, and the pork’s surface moisture will help adhere it elsewhere.

steps.headline: Roast the pork for an hour, or until the internal temperature reaches 150 °F (66 °C).
steps.description: For a 3 lb (1.4 kg) pork loin roasting at 375 °F (191 °C), this should take 60-75 minutes. After 60 minutes, stick a probe thermometer into the center of the roast to check the internal temperature. Return it to the oven for 5-minute intervals as needed. The interior temperature of the pork will rise to the recommended 160 °F (71 °C) after you pull it from the oven.

steps.headline: Cut and serve the pork after it rests for 5-10 minutes.
steps.description: After you pull the pork from the oven, cover it loosely with aluminum foil. Allow it to rest for at least 5 minutes, and ideally 10 minutes. Then, slice it and serve it! If you’re a garlic fan, try this with garlic mashed potatoes. Refrigerate any leftovers and use them within 3 days.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients while you preheat the oven at 450 °F (232 °C).
steps.description:
While the oven preheats, add the dried herbs and seasonings to a bowl and stir them together with a fork. Use the following amounts:
1 tsp (5 g) garlic powder
1 tsp (5 g) dried oregano
1 tsp (5 g) ground cumin
1 tsp (5 g) ground coriander
1 tsp (5 g) dried thyme
1 tsp (5 g) salt

steps.headline: Sprinkle the seasoning blend over the entire tenderloin.
steps.description: Use your thumb and fingertips on one hand to grab pinches of seasoning from the bowl, then sprinkle them over the tenderloin. Use your other hand to turn the tenderloin so all sides are evenly coated. Keep your “sprinkling” hand dry, or else the seasonings will clump up on your fingers!

steps.headline: Pat and press the seasoning mix into the pork.
steps.description: Give the tenderloin a gentle massage with your hands in order to help the seasoning blend adhere to the flesh. This patting and pressing, combined with the pork’s moisture, will be enough to stick the seasoning in place. Although seasonings like these are called “rubs,” it's better to lightly massage them into the flesh than to vigorously rub them in.

steps.headline: Saute the minced garlic in olive oil.
steps.description: Place a large skillet over medium-high heat and pour in 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of olive oil. Add 1 tsp (5 g) of minced garlic and saute it for 1 minute. Stir the garlic constantly to prevent it from burning. The olive oil should have a shimmer to it, but not be smoking. If it is, turn down the heat to medium. Make sure the skillet is large enough for the tenderloin to fit into.

steps.headline: Cook the tenderloin in the pan for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Use tongs to turn the tenderloin every 2-3 minutes so that all sides get a chance to sear. You want the entire pork roast to be browned (but not blackened) at the end of the 10 minutes. The pork won’t be cooked through yet—the goal here is simply to sear the exterior.

steps.headline: Roast the tenderloin in the 450 °F (232 °C) oven for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Transfer the pork to a roasting pan and place it in the preheated oven. 20 minutes should be sufficient to fully cook a 1.25 lb (570 g) tenderloin. After 20 minutes, check the internal temperature with a probe thermometer. If it doesn’t read at least 150 °F (66 °C), put the tenderloin back in the oven for a few more minutes.

steps.headline: Let the tenderloin rest for 10 minutes before serving.
steps.description: Loosely cover the roast with aluminum foil and leave on the stovetop in the roasting pan for 10 minutes. During this time, the internal temperature will rise to the recommended 160 °F (71 °C). At this point, you can remove the tenderloin to a cutting board to slice and serve. Try serving it with rice and roasted vegetables. Refrigerate any leftovers and use them within 3 days.
